question: Question_02_(a)
sols:
When we look at this series, all its terms are positive, and they are
clearly decreasing\begin{align*}e^{-\sqrt{k}}\end{align*} is getting smaller and smaller, as
is $1/\sqrt{k}$.

The integral test can be applied here. We know that

\begin{align*}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}} e^{-\sqrt{k}} \text{ converges if and only if } I = \int_1^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} e^{-\sqrt{x}} dx \text{ converges.}\end{align*}

The integral I is improper (the infinite range of integration), but it
can be evaluated with substitution. Set $u = \sqrt{x}$ then
$du = \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} dx$, and therefore
$\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} e^{-\sqrt{x}} dx = 2 e^{-u} du$.

\begin{align*}I = \lim_{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_1^R \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} e^{-\sqrt{x}} dx = \lim_{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_1^R 2 e^{-u} du = \lim_{R \rightarrow \infty} -2 e^{-u}|_1^R = 2e^{-1}\end{align*}

From the above computation, I converges, and so does the original
series.
